qas.question: Are masons allowed to divulge the secrets of each degree?

answers.text: Masons swear at each degree to keep the contents of that degree secret
on a Volume of Sacred Law

qas.question: In what branch can books, other than scripture, be used for the purpose of oath taking?
What can be considered a Volume of Sacred Law?

answers.text: whichever book of divine revelation is appropriate to the religious beliefs of the individual brother

qas.question: What can be considered a Volume of Sacred Math?
What are Masons required to have done in order to be protected?
What branch of Freemasonry requires books other than scripture?

context: The idea of Masonic brotherhood probably descends from a 16th-century legal definition of a brother as one who has taken an oath of mutual support to another. Accordingly, <a0_0><b7_0>Masons swear at each degree to <a6_0>keep the contents of that degree secret<b7_0/><a6_0/><a0_0/>, and to support and protect their brethren unless they <a4_0><b10_0>have broken the law<b10_0/><a4_0/>. In most Lodges the oath or obligation is taken <a1_0><b8_0>on a <a5_0>Volume of Sacred Law<b8_0/><a5_0/><a1_0/>, <a3_0><b9_0>whichever book of divine revelation is appropriate to the religious beliefs of the individual brother<b9_0/><a3_0/> (usually the Bible in the Anglo-American tradition). In <a2_0><b11_0>Progressive continental Freemasonry<b11_0/><a2_0/>, books other than scripture are permissible, a cause of rupture between Grand Lodges.
